facts.text: Appeals are from the Judgment and Order dated July 7 1953 of the Assam High Court in Civil Rules Nos. 147 and 148 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated July 7 1953, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rules Nos. 147 and 148 of 1952, K. Dophtary, Solicitor-

facts.text: Assam High Court dismissed appellants' application under Art. 226 challenging orders of Deputy Commissioner Shri B. L. Sen.

anchor.surface_text: Assam dismissing the appellants application under Art. 226 challenging the orders -of the first respondent Shri B. L. Sen, Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar,

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner Sibsagar allowed applications filed by labourers of Teok Tea Estate and Dalim Tea Estate under section 20 of Minimum Wages Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: whereby he allowed the applications filed on behalf of the labourers employed in the Teok Tea Estate and the Dalim Tea Estate under section 20 of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948

facts.text: Government of Assam issued notification No. GLR. 352/51/56 on March 11, 1952 fixing minimum wages for tea plantations effective from March 30, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On March 11, 1952, the Government of Assam, in exercise of the powers conferred by s. 3 read with sub-s. (2) of s. 5 of the Act issued the following notification No. GLR. 352/51/56.

facts.text: Minimum wages consist of basic wages and dearness allowance: adult male Rs. (As.12 basic + As.6 DA = 1/21? total), female As.11 basic + As.5 DA.

anchor.surface_text: is pleased to fix minimum wages, which will come into force with effect from the 30th March, 1952, consisting of basic wages and dearness allowance in terms of clause (1) of sub-section 1 of section 4

facts.text: Notification states existing tasks and hours of work may continue until further orders.

anchor.surface_text: These rates are exclusive of concessions enjoyed by the workers in respect of supplies of foodstuffs and other essential commodities and other amenities which will continue unaffected. -The existing tasks and hours

facts.text: By notification No. GLR. 44/51 dated April 16, 1952, Government introduced Minimum Wages Rules including Rule 24 on normal working day of 9 hours for adults, max 48/week.

anchor.surface_text: By notification No. GLR. 44/51, dated the 16th April, 1952, the said Government introduced the Minimum Wages Rules which, inter alia, provided Rule 24. Number of hours of work which shall constitute a normal

facts.text: Notification No. GLR. 352/51 dated May 12, 1952 explained 'may' as 'shall' for existing tasks and hours.

anchor.surface_text: By another notification No. GLR. 352/51 dated May 12, 1952, the said Government explained that the word may mentioned in the notification dated March 11, 1952, will have the force of shall .

facts.text: Prior to fixation, male labourers paid As.8/- per day for plucking 16 seers green leaves, females As.6/- for 12 seers, plus ticca 6 ps per extra seer.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to the fixation of the minimum wages consisting of basic wages and dearness allowance as aforesaid, the labourers engaged in plucking tea leave, in these tea estates used to be paid basic wages for male

facts.text: Payment worked out at 6 ps. per seer of green leaves.

anchor.surface_text: It may be noted -the payment of basic wages on the above computation also worked out at the rate of 6 ps. per seer of green leaves plucked by the labourers.

facts.text: After fixation, managers continued paying 6 ps per seer but refused extra unless exceeded 24 seers (males) /22 (females).

anchor.surface_text: Even after the fixation of the minimum wages by the said notification, the managers of these tea-estates continued to pay to the labourers wages at the rate of 6 ps. per seer of green leaves plucked by them.

facts.text: Labourers contended entitled to extra at 6 ps per seer over 16/12 seers.

anchor.surface_text: The labourers contended that the existing work-load or task at the date of the said notification was 16 seers for male labourers and 12 seers for female labourers and they were entitled to such extra payment

facts.text: Difference in payment: As.4/- per day males, As.5/- females.

anchor.surface_text: There was a difference thus in payment, of as. 4/- per day in the case of male labourers and as. 5/- per day in the case of female labourers

facts.text: Applications filed under s.20 to Deputy Commissioner for payment difference from March 30, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: This claim of theirs was the subject-matter of the applications filed on their behalf before the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, under s. 20 (2) of the Act. The applicants asked for directions under s. 20 (3)

facts.text: Managers contested applications: (1) not maintainable under s.20, (2) no fixed workload.

anchor.surface_text: The managers of the estates contested these applications mainly on two grounds viz., (1) that the applications were not maintainable under s. 20 of the Act, and (2) that there was no fixed workload or task

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner held applications maintainable and found workload 16/12 seers existed, ordered payment of basic for that + extra 6ps/seer over.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, who was the authority appointed under the Act to hear the claims arising out of the payment of less than the minimum rates of wages to these labourers, entertained the applications,

facts.text: Managers filed Art.226 applications in Assam High Court, dismissed, certificates granted.

anchor.surface_text: The managers of the estates thereupon filed applications under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the High Court of Judicature in Assam raising the -same contentions which had been negatived by the Deputy

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on December 21, 1956 by BHAGWATI J.

anchor.surface_text: 1956. December 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-,These two appeals with certificates under Art. 133 (1) (c) of the Constitution

facts.text: Both DC and HC found as fact that prior workload was 16 seers males, 12 females.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, and the High Court found as a fact that before the fixation of the minimum wages as above, there was a basic work-load or task of 16 seers of leaves for the male

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld that notification fixed minimum wage related to existing task, not pure time rate.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, propose to decide this question of jurisdiction as in the instant cases we have, in addition to the determination of the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, the adjudication of the main disputes

arguments.claim: Notification not merely time rate but related to existing workload/task; extra payable as per practice
Increasing basic wages without changing task shows relation to existing workload; no sense otherwise

anchor.surface_text: the sole intention of the Government... to increase these basic wages... while maintaining the same basic work-load or task... no sense whatever in increasing

arguments.claim: Proceedings by way of certiorari not of course; HC could refuse if no failure of justice
No interference warranted due to concurrent findings on merits, long pendency since 1952

holdings.text: what was fixed by the notification was not merely a minimum time rate irrespective of the existing work-load or task which used to be performed by the labourers but was a minimum wage which, though fixed for time work, was necessarily related to the work-load or task then being performed by these labourers so that whatever extra work was done by the labourers in excess of the existing work-load or task of plucking 16 seers of tea leaves in the case of male labourers and 12 seers of tea leaves in the case of female labourers had to be paid for in accordance with the practice then prevailing, whether it was based on agreement or ticca or custom, at the rate of 6 ps. per seer

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that what was fixed by the notification was not merely a minimum time rate irrespective of the existing work-load or task which used to be performed by the labourers- but was a minimum wage which, though fixed for time work, was necessarily related to the work-load or task then being performed by these labourers so that whatever extra work was done by the labourers in excess of the existing work-load or task of plucking 16 seers of tea leaves in the case of male labourers and 12 seers of tea leaves in the case of female labourers had to be paid for in accordance with the practice then prevailing, whether it was based on agreement or ticca or custom, at the rate of 6 ps. per seer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contention unsound because notification recognizes existing tasks to continue; prior basic wages calculated at 6 ps per seer for standard task; increasing basic wages while keeping tasks same relates wages to task; otherwise no benefit to workers

holdings.text: The conclusions reached in this behalf both by the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, and the High Court are, therefore, correct and cannot be challenged

anchor.surface_text: The conclusions reached in this behalf both by the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, and the High Court are, therefore, correct and cannot be challenged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts found workload of 16/12 seers proved by evidence and recognized in notification; SC endorses as part of wage interpretation

holdings.text: We do not propose to decide this question of jurisdiction as in the instant cases we have, in addition to the determination of the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, the adjudication of the main disputes between the parties by the High Court itself

anchor.surface_text: We do not, propose to decide this question of jurisdiction as in the instant cases we have, in addition to the determination of the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, the adjudication of the main disputes

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction avoided because merits already determined concurrently by lower courts and endorsed by SC

holdings.text: having regard to the circumstance that the matters have been pending since September, 1952, right up to the end of the year 1956, no useful purpose will be served by our interfering at this stage, as the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, and the High Court both came to the same conclusion, a conclusion which we also have endorsed above

anchor.surface_text: we feel that having regard to the circumstance that the matters have been pending since September, 1952, right up to the end of the year 1956, no useful purpose will be served by our interfering at this stage, as the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, and the High Court both came to the same conclusion, a conclusion which we also have endorsed above,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long pendency and concurrent merits findings on entitlement to wages preclude interference despite possible jurisdiction issue

holdings.text: Proceedings by way of certiorari are not of course. The High Court of Assam had the power to refuse the writs if it was satisfied that there was no failure of justice, and in these appeals which are directed against the orders of the High Court in applications under Art. 226, we could refuse to interfere unless we are satisfied that the justice of the case requires it. But we are not so satisfied
holdings.reasoning_summary: Certiorari discretionary; no failure of justice given concurrent merits findings in favor of respondents

holdings.text: This being the point of substance which has been decided in favour of the respondents, we are of the opinion that the appeals are liable to be dismissed

anchor.surface_text: This being the point of substance which has been decided in favour of the respondents, we are of the opinion that the appeals are liable to be dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed; no interference with orders of Deputy Commissioner and High Court; labourers entitled to basic wages for specified task and extra wages at 6 ps. per seer beyond that.
